mn104:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying in the land of the Sakyans near the village of Sāma.
mn104:2.1: Now at that time the Jain ascetic of the Ñātika clan had recently passed away at Pāvā.
mn104:2.2: With his passing the Jain ascetics split, dividing into two factions, arguing, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words:
mn104:2.3: “You don’t understand this teaching and training. I understand this teaching and training. What, you understand this teaching and training? You’re practicing wrong. I’m practicing right. I stay on topic, you don’t. You said last what you should have said first. You said first what you should have said last. What you’ve thought so much about has been disproved. Your doctrine is refuted. Go on, save your doctrine! You’re trapped; get yourself out of this—if you can!”
mn104:2.4: You’d think there was nothing but slaughter going on among the Jain ascetics.
mn104:2.5: And the Jain Ñātika’s white-clothed lay disciples were disillusioned, dismayed, and disappointed in the Jain ascetics. They were equally disappointed with a teaching and training so poorly explained and poorly propounded, not emancipating, not leading to peace, proclaimed by someone who is not a fully awakened Buddha, with broken monument and without a refuge.
mn104:3.1: And then, after completing the rainy season residence near Pāvā, the novice Cunda went to see Venerable Ānanda at Sāma village. He bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened.
mn104:4.2: “Reverend Cunda, we should see the Buddha about this matter.
mn104:4.3: Come, let’s go to the Buddha and inform him about this.”
mn104:4.5: Then Ānanda and Cunda went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and Ānanda informed him of what Cunda had said. He went on to say,
mn104:4.10: ‘When the Buddha has passed away, let no dispute arise in the Saṅgha.
mn104:4.11: For such a dispute would be for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.’”
mn104:5.2: Do you see even two mendicants who disagree regarding the things I have taught from my direct knowledge, that is,
mn104:5.3: the four kinds of mindfulness meditation, the four right efforts, the four bases of psychic power, the five faculties, the five powers, the seven awakening factors, and the noble eightfold path?”
mn104:5.6: Nevertheless, there are some individuals who appear to live obedient to the Buddha, but when the Buddha has passed away they might create a dispute in the Saṅgha regarding livelihood or the monastic code.
mn104:5.7: Such a dispute would be for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.”
mn104:5.8: “Ānanda, dispute about livelihood or the monastic code is a minor matter.
mn104:5.9: But should a dispute arise in the Saṅgha concerning the path or the practice, that would be for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.
mn104:6.1: Ānanda, there are these six roots of arguments.
mn104:6.3: Firstly, a mendicant is irritable and hostile.
mn104:6.4: Such a mendicant lacks respect and reverence for the teacher, the teaching, and the Saṅgha, and they don’t fulfill the training.
mn104:6.5: They create a dispute in the Saṅgha, which is for the hurt and unhappiness of the people, for the harm, hurt, and suffering of gods and humans.
mn104:6.6: If you see such a root of arguments in yourselves or others, you should try to give up this bad thing.
mn104:6.7: If you don’t see it, you should practice so that it doesn’t come up in the future.
mn104:6.8: That’s how to give up this bad root of arguments, so it doesn’t come up in the future.

mn104:12.1: There are four kinds of disciplinary issues.
mn104:12.3: Disciplinary issues due to disputes, accusations, offenses, or proceedings.

mn104:13.1: There are seven methods for the settlement of any disciplinary issues that might arise.
mn104:13.2: Removal in the presence of those concerned is applicable. Removal by accurate recollection is applicable. Removal due to recovery from madness is applicable. The offense should be acknowledged. The decision of a majority. A verdict of aggravated misconduct. Covering over with grass.

mn104:14.3: Those mendicants should all sit together in harmony

mn104:20.1: And how is there the covering over with grass?
mn104:20.2: It’s when the mendicants continually argue, quarrel, and dispute, doing and saying many things that are not proper for an ascetic.
mn104:20.3: Those mendicants should all sit together in harmony.
mn104:20.4: A competent mendicant of one party, having got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, and raised their joined palms, should inform the Saṅgha:
mn104:20.5: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
mn104:20.6: We have been continually arguing, quarreling, and disputing, doing and saying many things that are not proper for an ascetic.
mn104:20.7: If it seems appropriate to the Saṅgha, then—for the benefit of these venerables and myself—I disclose in the middle of the Saṅgha by means of covering over with grass any offenses committed by these venerables and by myself, excepting only those that are gravely blameworthy and those connected with laypeople.’
mn104:20.8: Then a competent mendicant of the other party, having got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, and raising their joined palms, should inform the Saṅgha:
mn104:20.9: ‘Sir, let the Saṅgha listen to me.
mn104:20.10: We have been continually arguing, quarreling, and disputing, doing and saying many things that are not proper for an ascetic.
mn104:20.11: If it seems appropriate to the Saṅgha, then—for the benefit of these venerables and myself—I disclose in the middle of the Saṅgha by means of covering over with grass any offenses committed by these venerables and by myself, excepting only those that are gravely blameworthy and those connected with laypeople.’
mn104:20.12: That’s how there is the covering over with grass. And that’s how certain disciplinary issues are settled, that is,
mn104:21.1: Ānanda, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
mn104:21.3: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.
mn104:21.4: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
mn104:21.5: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness …
mn104:21.6: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
mn104:21.7: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness …
mn104:21.8: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
mn104:21.9: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material possessions they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions.
mn104:21.10: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
mn104:21.11: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are unbroken, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion.
mn104:21.12: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
mn104:21.13: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and leads one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
mn104:21.14: This too is a warm-hearted quality.
mn104:21.15: These six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
mn104:22.1: If you should undertake and follow these six warm-hearted qualities, do you see any criticism, large or small, that you could not endure?”
mn104:22.3: “That’s why, Ānanda, you should undertake and follow these six warm-hearted qualities.
mn104:22.4: That will be for your lasting welfare and happiness.”
mn104:22.5: That is what the Buddha said.
mn104:22.6: Satisfied, Venerable Ānanda was happy with what the Buddha said.
